conclusion: The problem involves calculating the frictional force exerted by the ground on the long wooden board ab using principles of friction and equilibrium.
The frictional force exerted by the ground on the long wooden board ab is given by the friction coefficient μ1 between the board and the ground.

The frictional force f acting on the block P is given by μ2 × mg, where m is the mass of the block, g is the acceleration due to gravity, and μ2 is the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the board.

Since the block is sliding on the board without slipping, the frictional force f is equal to the normal force N minus the component of the block's weight mg parallel to the board, resulting in f = N - mg.
The normal force N is equal to the weight of the board M × g, so N = M × g.
Substituting N = M × g into the friction equation gives f = M × g - mg.
Since the block is stationary, the frictional force f is equal to the normal force N, so f = M × g.
The frictional force exerted by the ground on the long wooden board ab is M × g.
Since the block is stationary, the frictional force f is equal to the normal force N, which is M × g.
Thus, the magnitude of the frictional force exerted by the ground on the long wooden board ab is M × g.
The magnitude of the frictional force exerted by the ground on the long wooden board ab is M × g.
